awd_titl_txt: Chemotaxis sensing preference in plant-microbe associations
awd_abstract_narration:
Future food security will rely on increased crop yields using sustainable agricultural practices to meet the demands for food of the projected world population of 9.7 billion by 2050. The microbiome of the plant rhizosphere (the area around the root is known as the rhizosphere, and the group of microbes in an area is known as a microbiome), which can be compared to its human gut homolog, plays a critical role in plant health, ultimately affecting crop yield. Manipulation of the rhizosphere microbes is a proposed strategy for the achievement of sustainable agricultural practices. However, little is known regarding how most beneficial soil bacteria manage to find their target plants, and how they establish stable associations with the roots of plants once they find them. This gap in knowledge will be addressed by examining how bacteria deploy chemical detecting proteins on their surfaces and by studying how the signals from those sensing proteins enter and move around inside the cell. The work will provide detailed quantitative information about how beneficial soil bacteria precisely find their preferred zones on the root surface, and the results will  provide new tools for optimizing design of beneficial plant-bacteria associations. The project will have educational impact by providing research training for undergraduate and graduate students from diverse backgrounds, including those from underrepresented groups in STEM. The project will also engage deaf and hard of hearing students in research and thus enhance participation of this critically underserved and untapped pool of talent. 

This project will take advantage of the well-characterized chemotaxis response of the motile soil bacterium, Azospirillum brasilense, as a model because it is a suitable representative of root inhabiting bacteria and it is successfully used to promote the growth of diverse crops in sustainable agricultural practices. The experimental design combines proteomics, genetics and computational modeling to address how motile bacteria set sensing preferences for roots. First, the mechanisms underlying the assembly of distinct chemotaxis receptor arrays which are typical of many beneficial root colonizing bacteria will be established (Objective 1). Next, the dynamic changes in the composition of chemotaxis receptor clusters will be related with changes in bacteria sensing preference and competitiveness in the rhizosphere (Objective 2). Because chemotaxis emerges from a sophisticated signaling pathway, it is difficult to predict population behavior from molecular mechanisms. The experimental data will be integrated with computational modeling to quantitatively describe how motile bacteria set chemotaxis sensing preference with change in their metabolism to precisely accumulate at a specific position in a gradient (Objective 3). Results obtained will uncover the engineering principles for manipulation of and/or the synthetic design of chemotaxis sensing preferences in beneficial soil bacteria. This knowledge is critical to develop future strategies for rhizosphere microbiome optimization for sustainable agriculture.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit. Motile bacteria use chemotaxis and dedicated receptors to navigate their surroundings. Chemotaxis is a pre-requisite to the establishment of plant-microbe associations, including the association of beneficial soil bacteria with the roots of plants to promote plant health and growth. The aim of the project was to decipher how beneficial soil motile bacteria adjust their chemosensing preferences in response to their metabolism and changes in the environment. We have determined that chemoreceptors assembled into two spatially distinct chemotaxis signaling arrays and interact with signaling proteins from two  pathways, providing a mechanism to integrate sensing and signaling into a coordinated response. We have used a novel microsope slide-in-chamber as well as developed a root-in-pool assay to characterize the role of chemotaxis signaling and a subset of chemoreceptors in mediating attractant as well as repellent responses to distinct regions of the rhizosphere of wheat and alfalfa in our model system. We have also identified specific compounds in root exudates that mediate these behaviors in the rhizosphere. We have used a novel optogenetic system to manipulate c-di-GMP signaling in real-time and in a transient manner and showed that c-di-GMP binding to some chemotaxis receptors alters aerotaxis and modulate repellent responses to oxidative stress in our model system. Using proteomics, we have also identified novel signaling connections between chemotaxis arrays composition and metabolism, including nitrogen fixation. We have identified unexpected roles for some chemotaxis receptors in metabolism and maintenance of chemotaxis array structure at cell poles. These findings broaden the role of chemotaxis signaling arrays in bacterial cell physiology. Work under this award has also expanded the findings linking chemotaxis to metabolism to another model system, suggesting it is broadly shared by other bacteria. Data from this project demonstrate that chemotaxis signaling array composition and modification state (e.g. bound to c-di-GMP) determines sensing preferences and modulate chemotaxis and root surface colonization.

Broader Impacts. Under this award, we have published 10 peer-review manuscripts, presented findings at workshop and conferences (in-person and virtual) and trained 6 graduate students, 11 undergraduate students, one high school student and supported 5 Deaf and hard-of-hearing students for summer research projects thanks to an NSF supplement to this award. Students involved presented their work at local and national conferences. This research developed novel tools and methods that are applicable to other model systems. Work accomplished under this award deciphered unexpected and novel connections between chemoreceptors, metabolism and chemotaxis arrays signaling structure. These findings will impact synthetic biology by identifying novel targets and modules for engineering and provide a foundation for the development of improved bacterial strains used as bio-inoculants in sustainable agricultural practices.
